question_details.query: For agricultural landscapes, what are the most effective interventions for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians?
What interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians, such as refuges or hibernation sites?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Interventions reported for providing shelter habitats for amphibians include: creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites, which maintained great crested newt populations when implemented with other terrestrial habitat management, were used by common frog and smooth newts, and had four amphibian species recorded close to hibernacula at two of three sites [759]; creating refuges, including installing artificial refugia and reintroducing coarse woody debris, which helped maintain great crested newt populations when combined with other interventions, were used by translocated Hamilton’s frogs and by hellbenders (with few used for breeding), and showed mixed effects of adding coarse woody debris on amphibian abundance and species number, with one restoration project increasing frog species following reintroduction of coarse woody debris [772]; leaving coarse woody debris in forests, which yielded mixed responses, including no significant differences in abundance for many species when debris was retained vs removed, higher use of clearcuts with debris retained by migrating amphibians, and higher survival of juvenile amphibians in piles of woody debris compared to open areas and similar to unharvested forest [843]; and creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats, for which no studies were found that directly tested effects on amphibian populations [813].
summary_statements: Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites maintained great crested newt populations when implemented with other terrestrial habitat management.
Artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites were used by common frogs and smooth newts.
Four amphibian species were recorded close to artificial hibernacula at two of three monitored sites.
Creating refuges, including installing artificial refugia and reintroducing coarse woody debris, helped maintain great crested newt populations when combined with other interventions.
Refuges were used by translocated Hamilton’s frogs and by hellbenders.
Few hellbenders used created refuges for breeding.
Adding coarse woody debris showed mixed effects on amphibian abundance and species number.
One restoration project increased frog species following the reintroduction of coarse woody debris.
Leaving coarse woody debris in forests yielded mixed responses for amphibians.
No significant differences were found in the abundance of many amphibian species when coarse woody debris was retained versus when the debris was removed.
Migrating amphibians made higher use of clearcuts where coarse woody debris was retained.
Juvenile amphibians had higher survival in piles of woody debris compared to survival in open areas.
The survival of juvenile amphibians in piles of woody debris was similar to their survival in unharvested forest.
No studies were found that directly tested the effects on amphibian populations of creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats.

question_details.query: What factors and interventions have influenced the success of natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Creating ponds (often alongside other interventions) increased natterjack toad populations or maintained/increased populations at many sites; compared to natural ponds, created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation but higher mortality from invertebrate predation (866). 
- Translocations established breeding populations in 30–70% of cases; success was higher on dune or saltmarsh than heathland, and a UK study found populations increased at translocation sites, particularly with replicated translocations of wild rather than captive-bred toads (859). 
- Adding limestone to ponds showed mixed results in the UK: establishment of one of three translocated populations; temporary increases in breeding and increased larval/egg survival at some sites; but also high tadpole mortality, pond abandonment, and more abnormal common frog eggs at other sites (748). 
- Grazing management produced varied outcomes: a replicated, controlled UK study found grazed plots did not have higher natterjack abundance than ungrazed, while other studies that included reintroduction of grazing as part of habitat management maintained or increased natterjack populations (780). 
- Vegetation clearance, as part of broader habitat management and sometimes alongside releases, increased, stabilized or maintained natterjack populations; an England study recorded increased occupancy following vegetation clearance (761). 
- Deepening, de-silting or re-profiling ponds, when combined with other interventions, increased natterjack toad populations in UK studies (817).
summary_statements: Creating ponds, often alongside other interventions, increased natterjack toad populations or maintained/increased the populations at many sites.
Compared to natural ponds, created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation.
Compared to natural ponds, created ponds had higher mortality from invertebrate predation.
Translocations of natterjack toads established breeding populations in 30–70% of cases.
The success of natterjack toad translocations was higher on dune or saltmarsh habitats than on heathland.
A UK study found natterjack toad populations increased at translocation sites, particularly with replicated translocations of wild toads rather than captive-bred toads.
Adding limestone to ponds showed mixed results for natterjack toad conservation in the UK.
Adding limestone to ponds led to the establishment of one of three translocated natterjack toad populations.
At some sites, adding limestone to ponds resulted in temporary increases in natterjack toad breeding and increased larval or egg survival.
At other sites, adding limestone to ponds was associated with high tadpole mortality, pond abandonment, and more abnormal common frog eggs.
Grazing management for natterjack toads has produced varied outcomes.
A replicated, controlled UK study found that grazed plots did not have a higher abundance of natterjack toads than ungrazed plots.
Other studies found that the reintroduction of grazing as part of habitat management maintained or increased natterjack toad populations.
Vegetation clearance, as part of broader habitat management and sometimes alongside releases, increased, stabilized or maintained natterjack toad populations.
An England study recorded increased natterjack toad occupancy following vegetation clearance.
Deepening, de-silting or re-profiling ponds, when combined with other interventions, increased natterjack toad populations in UK studies.

question_details.query: What are the general outcomes and challenges associated with captive breeding programs for different amphibian groups like frogs, toads, and salamanders?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across frogs, many studies reported egg production in captivity, sometimes by captive‑bred females, with several cases of mixed success (some species or 17–50% of captive populations reproducing) and occasional failures; survival outcomes ranged from successful rearing to hatching, tadpoles, froglets, or adults, but included low froglet survival in some cases, and reproductive success depended on factors such as temperature and simulated wet/dry seasons, while development was affected by parental care, density, and temperature [835]. For salamanders, eggs were produced successfully in several studies, but success varied with tank habitat and was higher in semi‑natural than laboratory settings in some cases; some species produced eggs that did not hatch, one study reported 60% survival to hatching for Japanese giant salamanders, and larval development, body condition, and survival were influenced by water temperature, density, and rearing environment [838]. Hormone treatments commonly stimulated or increased sperm production and sometimes enabled successful captive breeding, but female responses were mixed (about 30–71% producing viable eggs depending on hormone regimes), and in some cases hormone‑induced breeding did not occur; eggs induced by hormones were sometimes raised to tadpoles or froglets, though two studies reported most toads died before or soon after hatching [883]. Using a surrogate species to refine husbandry promoted successful breeding of a critically endangered frog [1862]. Providing enclosure features (e.g., rotting logs, hollow bamboo, varied substrates) and simulating wet/dry seasons promoted breeding in captive frogs [1876], while altering enclosure lighting to add UV did not increase clutch size and was associated with greater fungal load [1865]. Cryopreservation showed that sperm viability after freezing varied by species, cryoprotectant, and storage/handling conditions, with some methods yielding higher viability, but overall viability could be low even though storage up to 58 weeks was possible [876].
summary_statements: Many studies on frogs reported egg production in captivity, sometimes by captive‑bred females.
Captive breeding programs for frogs have had mixed success, with some species or 17–50% of captive populations reproducing, alongside occasional failures.
Survival outcomes for captive-bred frogs ranged from successful rearing to hatching, tadpoles, froglets, or adults, but low froglet survival occurred in some cases.
The reproductive success of captive frogs depended on factors such as temperature and simulated wet and dry seasons.
The development of captive-bred frogs was affected by parental care, density, and temperature.
For salamanders, eggs were produced successfully in several studies, but success varied with tank habitat and was higher in semi‑natural than laboratory settings in some cases.
Some captive salamander species produced eggs that did not hatch.
One study reported 60% survival to hatching for Japanese giant salamanders.
For salamanders, larval development, body condition, and survival were influenced by water temperature, density, and the rearing environment.
Hormone treatments commonly stimulated or increased sperm production in amphibians and sometimes enabled successful captive breeding.
Female amphibian responses to hormone treatments were mixed, with about 30–71% producing viable eggs depending on the hormone regimes.
In some cases, hormone‑induced breeding did not occur in amphibians.
Amphibian eggs induced by hormones were sometimes raised to tadpoles or froglets.
Two studies reported that most toads from hormone-induced breeding died before or soon after hatching.
Using a surrogate species to refine husbandry promoted successful breeding of a critically endangered frog.
Providing enclosure features such as rotting logs, hollow bamboo, and varied substrates promoted breeding in captive frogs.
Simulating wet and dry seasons promoted breeding in captive frogs.
Altering enclosure lighting to add UV did not increase a frog's clutch size and was associated with a greater fungal load.
Cryopreservation studies showed that sperm viability after freezing varied by species, cryoprotectant, and storage or handling conditions.
While some cryopreservation methods yielded higher viability for amphibian sperm, overall viability could be low.
Storage of cryopreserved amphibian sperm for up to 58 weeks was possible.

question_details.query: As an alternative to creating entirely new ponds, what actions can be taken to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several ways to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians: Restoring existing ponds has been associated with increased species numbers, pond occupancy, breeding use, and maintained or increased populations in multiple studies, though effects varied by site and species [878]. Regulating or maintaining pond water levels has been linked to increased natterjack toad populations, maintained newt populations, successful breeding of dusky gopher frogs, and in some cases increased abundance and species numbers when ponds were seasonally drained [833]. Removing or controlling fish by periodically drying ponds has increased numbers of amphibian species and breeding success for several species in multiple studies [826]. Deepening, de-silting, or re-profiling ponds has been associated with establishment or increase of breeding populations and maintained or increased populations in several studies [817]. Reducing pond shading by removing tree canopy was part of restoration associated with establishment of breeding in translocated garlic toads, although one study found no increase in hatching success for spotted salamanders [758]. Excluding livestock or wild hogs by fencing has shown mixed effects overall but included increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads following restoration that included livestock exclusion [746]. Adding limestone to reduce acidification has produced varied outcomes, including temporary increases in breeding or higher larval/egg survival in some cases, but also high tadpole mortality or pond abandonment in others [748]. Managing surrounding vegetation and water quality through buffer approaches showed mixed results: planting riparian buffer strips along streams did not increase abundance or species numbers in one study [819]; retaining buffer strips during timber harvest had mixed to positive effects depending on species and buffer width [747]; and retaining or leaving unmown buffers around ponds increased numbers of frog species in one case, with mixed tadpole responses elsewhere [850]. Controlling invasive plants (e.g., swamp stonecrop, reed canarygrass) was associated with population increases or preferred egg-laying areas for some amphibians [823].
summary_statements: Restoring existing ponds for amphibians has been associated with increased species numbers, pond occupancy, and breeding use.
The restoration of existing ponds has been linked to maintained or increased amphibian populations in multiple studies.
The effects of restoring existing ponds for amphibians can vary by site and species.
Regulating or maintaining pond water levels has been linked to increased natterjack toad populations and maintained newt populations.
Regulating or maintaining pond water levels has been linked to the successful breeding of dusky gopher frogs.
The seasonal draining of ponds has, in some cases, led to increased amphibian abundance and species numbers.
Removing or controlling fish by periodically drying ponds has increased the numbers of amphibian species.
Removing or controlling fish by periodically drying ponds has increased breeding success for several amphibian species.
Deepening, de-silting, or re-profiling ponds has been associated with the establishment or increase of amphibian breeding populations.
Deepening, de-silting, or re-profiling ponds has been associated with maintained or increased amphibian populations.
Reducing pond shading by removing tree canopy was part of a restoration effort associated with the establishment of breeding in translocated garlic toads.
One study found that reducing pond shading by removing tree canopy did not increase hatching success for spotted salamanders.
Excluding livestock or wild hogs from ponds by fencing has shown mixed effects on amphibians overall.
Pond restoration that included livestock exclusion led to increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads.
Adding limestone to ponds to reduce acidification has produced varied outcomes for amphibians.
In some cases, adding limestone to ponds resulted in temporary increases in amphibian breeding or higher larval and egg survival.
In other cases, adding limestone to ponds has led to high tadpole mortality or pond abandonment by amphibians.
Managing surrounding vegetation and water quality for amphibians through buffer approaches has shown mixed results.
In one study, planting riparian buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance or species numbers.
Retaining buffer strips during timber harvest had mixed to positive effects on amphibians, depending on the species and buffer width.
Retaining or leaving unmown buffers around ponds increased the numbers of frog species in one case, while showing mixed tadpole responses elsewhere.
Controlling invasive plants, such as swamp stonecrop and reed canarygrass, was associated with population increases for some amphibians.
Controlling invasive plants was associated with creating preferred egg-laying areas for some amphibians.

question_details.query: Which vegetation management practices are most likely to benefit amphibian populations, and which are likely to be ineffective or harmful?
What key factors are associated with the success or failure of amphibian colonization and breeding in newly created ponds?
What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Antifungal drugs: Across 16 studies, 12 reported cure or increased survival following antifungal treatment, while four reported no cure but reduced infection levels or mixed results; six studies noted mortality or other adverse effects from specific fungicides [882]. Itraconazole specifically was effective at curing infections in six of eight studies; one study found reduced infection levels and one found mixed effects [882]. Field or pre-release treatment: A before-and-after study treating wild midwife toads with fungicide alongside pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis [767]. Probiotics/antimicrobial skin interventions: In four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, three found that adding antifungal bacteria to salamanders or frogs did not reduce infection rate or death, while one found prevention of infection and death; adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced infection rate of red-backed salamanders in one study; antimicrobial skin peptides given before or after infection did not increase survival of common toads; three studies found adding antifungal skin bacteria reduced weight loss in infected amphibians [764]. Heat/temperature treatment: In five studies (four replicated, controlled), four found that raising enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads, whereas one found that 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs [770].
summary_statements: Across 16 studies on antifungal drugs, 12 reported cure or increased survival following antifungal treatment.
In 16 studies on antifungal drugs, four reported no cure but did find reduced infection levels or mixed results.
Six studies noted mortality or other adverse effects from specific fungicides.
The antifungal drug Itraconazole was effective at curing infections in six of eight studies.
One study on Itraconazole found the drug reduced infection levels.
One study on Itraconazole found the drug had mixed effects.
A before-and-after study treating wild midwife toads with fungicide alongside pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.
In three of four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, adding antifungal bacteria to salamanders or frogs did not reduce infection rate or death.
In one of four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, adding antifungal bacteria to salamanders or frogs prevented infection and death.
Adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced the infection rate of red-backed salamanders in one study.
Antimicrobial skin peptides given before or after infection did not increase the survival of common toads.
Three studies found that adding antifungal skin bacteria reduced weight loss in infected amphibians.
In four of five studies, raising enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads.
One study found that a temperature of 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of retaining habitat features like riparian buffers, coarse woody debris, and snags during timber harvesting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Riparian buffers: For amphibians, studies comparing clearcuts with and without buffers reported mixed effects on abundance depending on species and buffer width, with one study finding higher abundance with buffers; compared to unharvested forest, some studies found similar abundance and composition, others found lower numbers; wider buffers sometimes supported greater species numbers and abundance, though not consistently (747). No studies were found assessing effects of riparian buffers during harvest on mammals or on butterflies and moths (2652; 3872). Coarse woody debris (CWD): In amphibians, retaining CWD in clearcuts produced no significant abundance difference for most species but overall amphibian responses (population, physiological, behavioural) were more negative where debris was retained; removing CWD in standing forest did not reduce diversity or overall abundance but reduced species richness in one study; migrating amphibians used clearcuts with retained debris more, and juvenile survival was higher in debris piles than open areas and similar to unharvested forest (843). In mammals, retaining/adding CWD yielded mixed outcomes: one study found more small mammal species groups where debris was present, another found higher numbers for two of three shrew species with increased CWD, while other studies reported no increase in small mammal numbers or records (2647). Gathering debris into piles increased mammal species richness and, in some cases, increased vole counts and small mammal abundance (2653). In reptiles, leaving debris after logging generally produced no changes in richness or abundance, though one study found higher richness and abundance than where debris was cleared and burned (3632). For birds, removing woody debris reduced overall breeding bird abundance and diversity and lowered nest survival for black-chinned hummingbirds, though some species increased after removal (345). Snags/standing deadwood: For reptiles, increasing snags and woody debris had mixed or no effects on diversity and abundance (3631). For amphibians, leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not increase salamander abundances compared to total clearcutting, did not prevent abundance declines or composition changes relative to unharvested plots, and reproductive metrics were similar or lower in harvested plots including those with retained dead/wildlife trees (845). Variable retention (retaining structural elements such as live trees/snags): bird responses were mixed, with nine species at higher densities and five at lower densities in variable-retention stands relative to controls (332).
summary_statements: For amphibians, studies comparing clearcuts with and without riparian buffers reported mixed effects on amphibian abundance, depending on the species and the buffer width.
One study on amphibians found higher abundance in clearcuts with riparian buffers compared to clearcuts without buffers.
Compared to unharvested forest, some studies found that riparian buffers had similar amphibian abundance and composition.
Compared to unharvested forest, some studies found lower numbers of amphibians in areas with riparian buffers.
Wider riparian buffers sometimes supported greater amphibian species numbers and abundance, though this finding was not consistent.
No studies were found assessing the effects of riparian buffers during timber harvest on mammals.
No studies were found assessing the effects of riparian buffers during timber harvest on butterflies and moths.
In amphibians, retaining coarse woody debris (CWD) in clearcuts produced no significant abundance difference for most species.
Overall amphibian responses, including population, physiological, and behavioural aspects, were more negative in clearcuts where coarse woody debris was retained.
Removing coarse woody debris in a standing forest did not reduce amphibian diversity or overall abundance.
One study found that removing coarse woody debris in a standing forest reduced amphibian species richness.
Migrating amphibians used clearcuts with retained coarse woody debris more than clearcuts without it.
Juvenile amphibian survival was higher in piles of coarse woody debris than in open areas.
Juvenile amphibian survival in piles of coarse woody debris was similar to survival in unharvested forest.
In mammals, retaining or adding coarse woody debris (CWD) yielded mixed outcomes.
One study found more small mammal species groups where coarse woody debris was present.
Another study found higher numbers for two of three shrew species when the amount of coarse woody debris was increased.
Other studies reported no increase in small mammal numbers or records when coarse woody debris was retained or added.
Gathering coarse woody debris into piles increased mammal species richness.
In some cases, gathering coarse woody debris into piles increased vole counts and small mammal abundance.
In reptiles, leaving coarse woody debris after logging generally produced no changes in species richness or abundance.
One study found higher reptile richness and abundance where debris was left after logging compared to where debris was cleared and burned.
For birds, removing woody debris reduced overall breeding bird abundance and diversity.
Removing woody debris lowered nest survival for black-chinned hummingbirds.
The populations of some bird species increased after the removal of woody debris.
For reptiles, increasing snags and woody debris had mixed or no effects on species diversity and abundance.
For amphibians, leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not increase salamander abundances compared to total clearcutting.
Leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not prevent amphibian abundance declines or composition changes relative to unharvested plots.
Amphibian reproductive metrics were similar or lower in harvested plots, including those with retained dead or wildlife trees.
Bird responses to variable retention, which involves retaining structural elements like live trees and snags, were mixed.
Nine bird species were found at higher densities in variable-retention stands relative to control areas.
Five bird species were found at lower densities in variable-retention stands relative to control areas.

question_details.query: What actions are available to mitigate the impacts of agricultural pollution on amphibian populations?
How effective are conservation actions such as legal protection, habitat creation, and translocation for great crested newt populations in the UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from UK-focused action documents indicates mixed effectiveness. For translocation, four of six studies (including one review and one replicated study) in the UK found translocated great crested newts maintained or established breeding populations; however, populations were present one year after release in 37% of cases, one study reported breeding failed in 48% of ponds within three years, and a systematic review of 31 great crested newt studies found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including translocations resulted in self-sustaining populations; a UK review reported reproduction following 56% of translocations, sometimes alongside head-starting and/or habitat management [858]. For habitat creation, creating ponds led to breeding populations at 57–75% of created ponds or sites in studies from Germany and the UK; a UK systematic review concluded there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, often including pond creation, produced self-sustaining populations; up to 88% of created ponds were colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing great crested newts, and head-started newts reproduced in 38% of created ponds [863]. For terrestrial habitat structures, one replicated before-and-after UK study found artificial hibernacula provided with other terrestrial habitat management maintained great crested newt populations; other replicated studies reported created hibernacula were used by common frog and smooth newts but not great crested newts, and four amphibian species were found close to hibernacula at two of three sites [759]. Regarding legal protection in the development context, three reviews (including a systematic review) in the Netherlands and UK found legal protection of amphibians was not effective at protecting populations during development, while two UK reviews reported that great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales [779].
summary_statements: Evidence from UK-focused action documents indicates mixed effectiveness for great crested newt conservation.
Four of six studies in the UK found translocated great crested newts maintained or established breeding populations.
Following translocation, great crested newt populations were present one year after release in 37% of cases.
One study reported that breeding by great crested newts failed in 48% of ponds within three years of translocation.
A systematic review of 31 great crested newt studies found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including translocations resulted in self-sustaining populations.
A UK review reported great crested newt reproduction following 56% of translocations, sometimes alongside head-starting and/or habitat management.
Creating ponds for great crested newts led to breeding populations at 57–75% of created ponds or sites in studies from Germany and the UK.
A UK systematic review concluded there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, often including pond creation, produced self-sustaining populations of great crested newts.
Up to 88% of created ponds were colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing great crested newts.
Head-started great crested newts reproduced in 38% of created ponds.
One replicated before-and-after UK study found artificial hibernacula, when provided with other terrestrial habitat management, maintained great crested newt populations.
Other replicated studies reported created hibernacula were used by common frog and smooth newts but not by great crested newts.
Four amphibian species were found close to hibernacula at two of three sites.
Three reviews in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibians was not effective at protecting populations during development.
Two UK reviews reported that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued in England and Wales increased to over 600 over a 10-year period.

question_details.query: What is the evidence regarding the long-term success and timeframes for amphibian populations to respond to habitat restoration, such as replanting or vegetation clearance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Vegetation clearance, often combined with other habitat management and sometimes animal releases, increased numbers of frog species or increased, stabilized, or maintained natterjack toad populations; one study reported increased occupancy by natterjack toads, and another found a great crested newt population was maintained for the first six years after management that included vegetation clearance but not in the longer term [761]. Replanting-based restoration showed amphibian abundance or community composition similar to natural sites after tree planting, or becoming more similar with increasing time since grassland reseeding; numbers of frog species increased following restoration that included planting shrubs and trees; after logging, planted forests with herbicide had amphibian abundance lower or similar to naturally regenerating forests depending on species and forest age; amphibians colonized replanted forest, reseeded grassland, and seeded/transplanted upland habitats; wetlands in reseeded grasslands were used more frequently than those in farmland but less than in natural grasslands [849].
summary_statements: Vegetation clearance, often combined with other habitat management and animal releases, increased the numbers of frog species.
Vegetation clearance, often combined with other habitat management and animal releases, increased, stabilized, or maintained natterjack toad populations.
One study reported increased occupancy by natterjack toads following management that included vegetation clearance.
A great crested newt population was maintained for the first six years after management that included vegetation clearance.
The great crested newt population was not maintained in the longer term following management that included vegetation clearance.
After tree planting, replanting-based restoration showed amphibian abundance or community composition similar to natural sites.
Amphibian communities in reseeded grasslands became more similar to natural sites with increasing time since reseeding.
The numbers of frog species increased following restoration that included planting shrubs and trees.
After logging, planted forests with herbicide had an amphibian abundance that was lower or similar to naturally regenerating forests, depending on the species and forest age.
Amphibians colonized replanted forest, reseeded grassland, and seeded or transplanted upland habitats.
Wetlands in reseeded grasslands were used more frequently by amphibians than wetlands in farmland.
Wetlands in reseeded grasslands were used less frequently by amphibians than wetlands in natural grasslands.

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different habitat management practices on agricultural land for amphibian conservation?
What management options are available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations?
What are the most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Wetland restoration: In site comparisons, most studies found restored wetlands had amphibian abundance, species numbers, or communities similar to natural wetlands; some found lower numbers or different communities; a global review reported 89% of cases showed similar or higher abundance or species numbers in restored/created vs natural wetlands (879). Multiple studies found restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, with breeding populations establishing in some cases; effects varied among species and were influenced by wetland size, proximity to source ponds, and seasonality, but not wetland age; restored wetlands were colonized by 3–8 amphibian species, though one study found three target species did not recolonize (879). Pond restoration: Across before-and-after studies, restoration and creation often increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, increased pond occupancy, and increased the number of ponds with breeding success; some studies found no increase or mixed effects depending on species or site; colonization of restored/created ponds ranged from 6–65% of ponds, with 35% used for breeding in one set of studies (878). Wetland creation: Site comparisons commonly found similar amphibian species numbers or abundance to natural wetlands, though some studies reported fewer species or lower abundance; created wetlands were colonized or used by 4–15 amphibian species; numbers of species and abundance were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence, and distance to source wetlands; a review and studies combining created and restored wetlands found species numbers and abundance higher or similar than natural wetlands in most cases (880). Pond creation: All studies reported amphibians used some or all created ponds; in comparisons with natural ponds, numbers of species or breeding species were often similar or higher, though species composition frequently differed and populations could be less stable; stable populations established in 50–100% of created ponds in some studies; use occurred in 64–100% and reproduction in 2–68% of created ponds depending on species; up to 15 species colonized and up to 10 reproduced; outcomes were influenced by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, and fish presence (869). Riparian buffer strips: Planting buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or adult-to-tadpole ratios in one replicated, controlled study (819).
summary_statements: In site comparisons, most studies found restored wetlands had amphibian abundance, species numbers, or communities similar to natural wetlands.
Some studies comparing restored and natural wetlands found lower amphibian numbers or different amphibian communities.
A global review reported that in 89% of cases, restored or created wetlands showed similar or higher amphibian abundance or species numbers compared to natural wetlands.
Multiple studies found that wetland restoration increased the numbers of amphibian species.
Breeding populations of amphibians established in some restored wetlands.
The effects of wetland restoration on amphibians varied among species.
The success of wetland restoration for amphibians was influenced by wetland size, proximity to source ponds, and seasonality, but not wetland age.
Restored wetlands were colonized by 3 to 8 amphibian species, though one study found three target species did not recolonize.
Across before-and-after studies, pond restoration and creation often increased numbers of amphibian species and maintained or increased amphibian populations.
Pond restoration and creation often increased pond occupancy by amphibians and increased the number of ponds with breeding success.
Some studies on pond restoration found no increase in amphibian numbers or mixed effects depending on the species or site.
Colonization of restored or created ponds by amphibians ranged from 6% to 65% of ponds, with 35% used for breeding in one set of studies.
Site comparisons commonly found created wetlands have similar amphibian species numbers or abundance to natural wetlands.
Some studies reported that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower amphibian abundance compared to natural wetlands.
Created wetlands were colonized or used by 4 to 15 amphibian species.

The numbers of amphibian species and their abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence, and distance to source wetlands.
A review and studies combining created and restored wetlands found amphibian species numbers and abundance were higher or similar to natural wetlands in most cases.
All studies reported that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
In comparisons with natural ponds, the numbers of amphibian species or breeding species in created ponds were often similar or higher.
The species composition of amphibians in created ponds frequently differed from natural ponds, and populations could be less stable.
Stable amphibian populations established in 50% to 100% of created ponds in some studies.
Depending on the species, amphibian use occurred in 64% to 100% of created ponds, and reproduction occurred in 2% to 68% of created ponds.
Up to 15 amphibian species colonized created ponds, and up to 10 of those species reproduced.
Outcomes of pond creation for amphibians were influenced by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, the surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, and fish presence.
Planting buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or adult-to-tadpole ratios in one replicated, controlled study.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using chemical treatments for amphibian conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Antifungal treatments for chytridiomycosis cured infections or increased survival in most reported studies, though some studies found only reduced infection levels or mixed results [882]. Itraconazole specifically was effective at curing amphibians in most tests, with some studies showing reduced infection levels or mixed effects [882]. Some specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians [882]. Pond drying combined with fungicidal treatment reduced infection levels in resident midwife toads but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis [766]. Adding salt to a pond where chytrid fungus was present was followed by a green and golden bell frog population remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months [762]. Disinfectant use for sterilizing equipment showed no evidence on disease spread outcomes; Virkon S did not affect survival, mass or behavior of frog and toad larvae, while bleach significantly reduced tadpole survival in one study [768].
summary_statements: Antifungal treatments for chytridiomycosis cured infections or increased survival in most reported studies.
Some studies found that antifungal treatments for chytridiomycosis only reduced infection levels or produced mixed results.
Itraconazole was effective at curing amphibians in most tests.
Some studies show Itraconazole resulted in reduced infection levels or had mixed effects.
Some specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians.
Pond drying combined with fungicidal treatment reduced infection levels in resident midwife toads.
Combining pond drying with fungicidal treatment did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.
Adding salt to a pond where chytrid fungus was present was followed by a green and golden bell frog population remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months.
Disinfectant use for sterilizing equipment showed no evidence of affecting disease spread outcomes.
The disinfectant Virkon S did not affect survival, mass or behavior of frog and toad larvae.
Bleach significantly reduced tadpole survival in one study.

question_details.query: As an alternative to treating infected individuals, what environmental management actions can help control chytridiomycosis in the wild?
